section.title: any/every/no/some
section.sectiontitle: Any and every can both be used to talk in general about all the members of a group.
section.text1a: You can get an excellent meal in any restaurant in this street.
section.text2a: You can get an excellent meal in every restaurant in this street.
section.sectiontitle2: Every looks at things together. It means all or this and that and the other.
section.text3: Do all your products have guarantees?
section.text3a: Yes. We guarantee every product we sell.
section.text4: Is there enough food for me and my four friends?

section.title: any/every/no/some
section.sectiontitle: Any looks at things separately, one at a time. It means this or that or the other.
section.text1a: Will any of those shoes fit me?
section.sectiontitle2: Any can also mean 'It doesn't matter which one'.
section.text3a: I don't mind. Any of them are fine.

section.title: any/every/no/some
section.text1a: There's nothing we can do to change his mind.
section.sectiontitle2: Some is used in questions when we expect people to answer 'Yes'.
